stream_context.summary: Kaze spends a bonus day off-work stream refining the Western-style "train town" course: polishing train/bandit effects, adding NPC dialogue, placing coins, and—after a long debugging session—getting the vanilla Pokey enemy working while wrestling with N64 RAM limits.

development_findings.summary: Bandit trains now include visual effects, sound effects, and camera shake to convey impact.
development_findings.quote: We did some really cool effects here. They now have VFX, they have SFX, they have the camera shake.

development_findings.summary: Shopfronts are shown as "robbed" so the team can skip modeling inventory and save RAM.
development_findings.quote: This is a trick we do so we don't actually have to 3D model the stuff here because we are getting pretty close to running out of RAM.

development_findings.summary: Three Yoshi coins and additional standard coins were placed, especially along train tracks, to make the area feel alive and guide exploration.
Severe memory pressure (≈49 MB, 40 k triangles) forced removal of the planned Yoshi Ranch sub-area and prompted collision and triangle budget cuts.
development_findings.quote: We might need to be able to load data per area… I'm fine with cutting out the Yoshi Ranch. I think that was unnecessary fluff anyway.

development_findings.summary: Kaze debugged and restored vanilla Pokey behaviour; issue traced to 37 ray-casts per frame that clashed with his engine’s ‘no-velocity, no-raycast’ optimisation.
development_findings.quote: I knew they were gonna do 25. I didn’t know they were gonna do 36. …Pokey needs 6 Raycasts? Actually, 37!

development_findings.summary: Pokey adjustments: scaled body parts (0.7), billboard fix, reduced shadow size, spawn distance raised to 5000 and despawn to 6000.
Random-rotation table was upgraded so every tumbleweed/train rotation is unique (1 in 65 536) enabling potential cheat detection.
development_findings.quote: In this game, every rotation is unique, because we actually use a signed approximation algorithm instead of a rounded LUT.

development_findings.summary: Considering per-area data loading, removing effect/command banks, and shrinking collision to reclaim memory; overlay debug tools used to inspect free space.
Lighting tweaks: switched some textures to multiply by shade colour alpha after Biobak feedback; avoided Mario 64 metallic look on models.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is on a one-week vacation from his day job at Gears for Breakfast, enabling bonus streams.
context_findings.quote: It's a bonus stream because I'm off work for this week.

context_findings.summary: PayPal froze his account after a pending identity verification; donations fail, causing on-stream frustration.
context_findings.quote: They asked me to verify my identity three months ago… now they just closed my account basically.

context_findings.summary: Maintains rigorous strength training; recently benched 315 lbs and needs more rest days due to heavier loads.
context_findings.quote: I feel like I haven't been able to recover from my bench in a while… I increased the weight so much.

context_findings.summary: Personal taste: dislikes 2D platformers, boss fights, and idioms; prefers concise, precise language.
context_findings.quote: I very much hate most games… Idioms are really dumb.

biobak.summary: Provided feedback on character teeth shading and metallic look, prompting lighting fixes.

badub.summary: Soundtrack uses ~70 % vanilla SM64 sound-font but arranged creatively for a fresh feel.
badub.quote: Most of it is still the default Mario 64 sound font… but they're used in really creative ways.

zeina.summary: Kaze asked Zeina to model a tumbleweed store facade and animate Pokey segments.
zeina.quote: I gotta ask Zeina to make a tumbleweed store here… Gonna ask Zeina to make animations for this guy here.

key_stories.title: The Pokey Debug Saga
key_stories.summary: While importing the vanilla Pokey enemy, every body segment floated and vanished. Kaze traced the bug to his engine’s optimisation that skipped floor ray-casts for stationary objects—Pokey actually performs 37 ray-casts per frame. After re-enabling floor checks and fixing billboard scaling, the enemy now works.
key_stories.challenge: Pokey segments spawned invisible and at wrong heights.
key_stories.process: Stubbed out code, added debug prints, compared to vanilla behaviour, restored constant floor updates.
key_stories.outcome: Pokey works; spawn/despawn distances and shadows tuned.
key_stories.key_quote: We finally fixed it… It was doing 36 ray-casts every tick!

key_stories.title: Running Out of RAM
key_stories.summary: The desert course hit the N64’s 64 MB ceiling, crashing on load. Kaze used overlay memory tools, cut 400 collision triangles, considered per-area loading, and ultimately removed the Yoshi Ranch sub-area.
key_stories.challenge: Level crashed due to memory exhaustion (~40 k tris, many textures).
key_stories.process: Measured free space, trimmed geometry, debated removing effect banks, and deleted the Ranch.
key_stories.outcome: Level now loads; future areas will be planned with stricter budgets.
key_stories.key_quote: We are out of memory. Cool, cool, cool… I'm fine with cutting out the Yoshi Ranch.

key_stories.title: Donation System Meltdown
key_stories.summary: Streamlabs sent viewer tips to Kaze’s obsolete German PayPal, which PayPal had frozen after an unprocessed ID check, blocking music requests and revenue.
key_stories.process: Checked Streamlabs, identified wrong email routing, recounted PayPal verification limbo.
key_stories.outcome: Issue unresolved on-stream; future fix required.
key_stories.key_quote: How is this going to the wrong email address? This makes no sense.
